thread.title: Topps Tiles explains why it's stockpiling top selling products ahead of Brexit

title: Topps Tiles explains why it's stockpiling top selling products ahead of Brexit

Topps Tiles is stocking up on top selling products in case of Brexit disruption.
The Leicestershire business – which posted positive annual results today – said it was buying in enough of its biggest sellers to tide it over for five or six weeks when Britain leaves the EU on March 29.
The business, based in Grove Park, is also keeping an eye on other possible Brexit implications including a drop in consumer confidence resulting in lower sales, and a reduced labour pool.
It comes in the wake of similar stockpiling plans from the likes of Mr Kipling cakes firm Premier Foods, Majestic Wine and catering giant Compass.
Topps Tiles chief financial officer Rob Parker said: “There’s a reasonable degree of uncertainty.
“We are building up a bit of stock heading into next year in case there is disruption of stock into the UK. Matthew Williams, chief executive of Topps Tiles in their Enderby headquarters.
“The plan is to focus on the top 100 key selling items, probably bringing in five to six weeks cover on those lines in the event that there is any short-term disruption.”
Topps Tiles chief executive Matt Williams said there was less concern over staff from Europe having difficulties staying in the UK and he didn’t expect consumer confidence to get worse, having already taken a hit following the actual 2016 referendum.
Mr Williams said: “I think the consumer is remarkably resilient but we are confident that we are going to continue to outperform the market.
“We are really keen to continue to move the retail business forward, putting digital at the centre of what we are doing as it becomes even more important for customers, so that by the time they make it to one of our stores they are committed to shopping with us.” Read More
